questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of a 2-hour history of swelling and severe pain in his left lower leg. He has no history of serious illness or trauma. His father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 30 years. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. He appears distressed. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and mildly swollen left lower leg; dorsiflexion of the left foot causes severe pain in the calf. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 184,000/mm3, prothrombin time of 11 seconds, partial thromboplastin time of 26 seconds, and positive fibrin split products. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows incompressibility of the popliteal vein with a hyperechoic mass and absent blood flow. The patient is administered a 5000 IU intravenous bolus of unfractionated heparin followed by a constant infusion. Six hours later, the partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated levels of homocysteine can be seen in patients with mutations in enzymes that metabolize homocysteine (autosomal recessive), vitamin B12 deficiency, and vitamin B6 deficiency. Hyperhomocysteinemia is considered a risk factor for thrombosis as it alters the function of thrombomodulin, factor VII, and factor V. Excess homocysteine also damages the vasculature leading to decreased endothelial antithrombotic activity. However, this patient has no evidence of anemia due to vitamin B6 or B12 deficiency (fatigue, pallor, tachycardia) or a family history of metabolic disease (enzyme deficiency). Moreover, homocysteine plays no role in heparin's mechanism of action and, therefore, does not affect the efficacy of heparin.

B) CORRECT:

Antithrombin III deficiency (AT III deficiency) is an inherited autosomal dominant hypercoagulable disease. AT III inhibits coagulation by binding to and inactivating the coagulation factors II (thrombin) and X. Heparin works by potentiating the binding of AT III to thrombin and factor X. This patient's PTT remains normal despite heparin administration because heparin requires AT III to achieve its effect. Patients with AT III deficiency can tolerate higher doses of heparin (also known as heparin resistance) without showing any changes in PTT. If therapeutic goals are not achieved with heparin (1.5 to 2.5 times the upper limit of the normal range of PTT), additional antithrombin concentrate may be needed.

See “Pathophysiology of hereditary thrombophilia” table.
Image Description:

Clotting homeostasis is maintained through a balance of procoagulation (purple) and anticoagulation (gray) processes. The procoagulation pathway ultimately results in the enzymatic conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin, which is an integral part of blood clot formation. The procoagulation pathway is physiologically inhibited through two distinct anticoagulation pathways, using either antithrombin III or the APC complex.

Antithrombin III inactivates factors IX, X, and thrombin. This process is accelerated in the presence of heparin. Additionally, antithrombin III indirectly increases the activation of plasmin through the action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), resulting in the degradation of both fibrinogen and fibrin.

The APC complex pathway involves the activity of thrombomodulin, a membrane protein expressed on endothelial cells that activates protein C. Activated protein C then binds to protein S to form the APC complex, which inactivates procoagulation factors V and VIII. The procoagulation factor thrombin can also activate protein C, which results in a negative feedback loop on the procoagulation pathway.

C) INCORRECT:

The altered factor V in Factor V Leiden is immune to the regulatory effect of protein C. Overactivity of factor V results in excessive activation of prothrombin, leading to a hypercoagulable state. Because neither protein C nor factor V interacts with heparin, its efficacy is unaffected in patients with Factor V Leiden.

D) INCORRECT:

Protein C deficiency is an autosomal dominant hypercoagulable disease caused by overactivity of factors V and VIII, which are normally inhibited by protein C. Heparin, on the other hand, acts on thrombin and factor Xa, not on factors V and VIII, so its anticoagulant action is unaffected by protein C deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is an acquired hypercoagulable disease caused by antiphospholipid antibodies (e.g., lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibodies, anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies). This condition would not prevent an increase of PTT because antibodies play no role in heparin's mechanism of action, so it is not a likely cause of this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: This young man presents with deep vein thrombosis (swollen, tender leg with positive Homan sign, positive D-dimer, positive ultrasonography signs). Despite receiving a therapeutic dose of heparin, his partial thromboplastin time (PTT) hardly increases and remains within normal limits, suggesting a defect in the protein targeted by heparin.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and swelling of her left leg over the past 24 hours. The pain is worse while walking and improves when resting. Seven months ago, she was diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism and was started on warfarin. Anticoagulant therapy was discontinued 1 month ago. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient does not smoke. She currently takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. On physical examination, the left calf is diffusely erythematous, swollen, and tender. Dorsal flexion of the left foot elicits pain. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. On duplex ultrasonography, the left popliteal vein is not compressible. Laboratory studies show an elevated serum concentration of D-dimer and insensitivity to activated protein C. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antithrombin III deficiency accounts for ∼ 0.1% of inherited cases of hypercoagulability and leads to a procoagulable state because of increased levels of thrombin and factor X. Neither of these factors is mentioned in this patient's laboratory studies.

B) INCORRECT:

Protein S along with protein C are natural anticoagulants in the body. When protein C is activated by thrombin, it combines with protein S to inhibit factor Va and factor VIIIa. Deficiency of protein S can therefore lead to hypercoagulability. However, protein S deficiency has a prevalence of < 1% in the general population, which makes another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is caused by acquired antibodies directed against phospholipids bound to plasma proteins such as lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, and anti-β2-glycoprotein I. This interaction leads to the aggregation of clotting factors, resulting in thrombus formation. Although this patient has a family history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and presents with hypercoagulability, her lack of other typical manifestations of SLE (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity, arthritis) makes this diagnosis less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Mutation of coagulation factor V (Factor V Leiden) does not allow activated protein C, a potent anticoagulant, to inhibit the coagulation cascade, leading to a procoagulant state by activation of prothrombin into thrombin (i.e., thrombophilia). Consider a hereditary thrombophilia in a young, otherwise healthy patient with venous thromboembolism with no obvious risk factors. Factor V Leiden is the most common inherited thrombophilia.

See table “Pathophysiology of hereditary thrombophilia.”
Image Description:

Clotting homeostasis is maintained through a balance of procoagulation (purple) and anticoagulation (gray) processes. The procoagulation pathway ultimately results in the enzymatic conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin, which is an integral part of blood clot formation. The procoagulation pathway is physiologically inhibited through two distinct anticoagulation pathways, using either antithrombin III or the APC complex.

Antithrombin III inactivates factors IX, X, and thrombin. This process is accelerated in the presence of heparin. Additionally, antithrombin III indirectly increases the activation of plasmin through the action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), resulting in the degradation of both fibrinogen and fibrin.

The APC complex pathway involves the activity of thrombomodulin, a membrane protein expressed on endothelial cells that activates protein C. Activated protein C then binds to protein S to form the APC complex, which inactivates procoagulation factors V and VIII. The procoagulation factor thrombin can also activate protein C, which results in a negative feedback loop on the procoagulation pathway.

E) INCORRECT:

The prothrombin mutation (G20210A) is the second most common hereditary cause of hypercoagulability. The mutation leads to increased expression of prothrombin. Prothrombin is activated by factor V, resulting in thrombin which then activates fibrinogen into fibrin to stabilize blood clots. However, this patient's insensitivity to activated protein C makes another cause of her symptoms more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevated levels of homocysteine can be seen in patients with mutations in enzymes that metabolize homocysteine (autosomal recessive), vitamin B12 deficiency, and vitamin B6 deficiency. Hyperhomocysteinemia is considered a risk factor for thrombosis as it alters the function of thrombomodulin, factor VII, and factor V. Excess homocysteine also damages the vasculature leading to decreased endothelial antithrombotic activity. However, this patient has no evidence of anemia due to vitamin B6 or B12 deficiency (fatigue, pallor, tachycardia) or family history of metabolic disease (enzyme deficiency). Moreover, insensitivity to activated protein C is suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Protein C along with protein S are natural anticoagulants in the body. When protein C is activated by thrombin, it complexes with protein S to inhibit factor Va and factor VIIIa. Protein C deficiency is a rare disease with a prevalence of < 1%. Moreover, laboratory results in this patient are not consistent with protein C deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's history of pulmonary embolism, warfarin use, and clinical features of calf tenderness, swelling, erythema, elevated D-dimer, and noncompressible popliteal vein indicate a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. Her laboratory studies implicate insensitivity to activated protein C as the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of right leg pain. The pain is worse while walking and improves when resting. Eight months ago, she was diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism and was started on warfarin. Anticoagulant therapy was discontinued two months ago. Her mother had systemic lupus erythematosus. On examination, her right calf is diffusely erythematous, swollen, and tender. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. On duplex ultrasonography, the right popliteal vein is not compressible. Laboratory studies show an elevated serum level of D-dimer and insensitivity to activated protein C. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Loss of plasma antithrombin in urine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is due to acquired antibodies directed against phospholipids bound to plasma proteins such as lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, and beta2-glycoprotein I. This interaction leads to aggregation of clotting factors, which result in thrombus formation. Although this patient has a family history of SLE and presents with hypercoagulability, the lack of additional findings, such as malar rash, photosensitivity, and arthritis, make SLE less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Protein S along with Protein C are natural anticoagulants in the body. When protein C is activated by thrombin, it complexes with protein S to inhibit factor Va and factor VIIIa. Deficiency of protein S can lead to hypercoagulability, but it is a rather rare disease only accounting for ∼ 1%. Thus, it is not the best answer choice.

C) INCORRECT:

Loss of plasma antithrombin in urine, along with an increase in blood viscosity due to extravasation of fluid from albumin loss in urine, is the pathophysiology of thrombophilia in nephrotic syndrome. However, this patient lacks the typical features of nephrotic syndrome (e.g., edema, weight gain, frothy urine), and instead, she presents with insensitivity to activated protein C, which cannot be explained by nephrotic syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Coagulation factor VIII is part of the intrinsic pathway and is bound to von Willebrand factor. Elevated levels, in combination with factor IXa, activates factor X into factor Xa which results in a hypercoagulable state (i.e., thrombophilia). Although this patient's presentation could be explained by an elevated factor VIII, insensitivity to activated protein C makes another cause more likely.
Image Description:

The coagulation cascade is a series of events that results in the formation of a stable thrombus. There are two pathways that can activate the coagulation cascade:

- The extrinsic pathway is activated by endothelial injury that exposes tissue factor (factor III) present on endothelial fibroblasts to circulating factor VII, forming a complex that activates factor X.

- The intrinsic pathway is initiated by the activation of factor XII that eventually leads to activation of factor IX, which then activates factor X.

The common pathway begins with activated factor X that converts prothrombin to thrombin. Thrombin activates fibrinogen to fibrin monomers and also stimulates platelet activation and aggregation. Thrombin also activates factor XIII (fibrin stabilizing factor), which cross-links fibrin monomers and activated platelets to form a stable clot (red thrombus).

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated levels of homocysteine can be seen in patients with mutations in enzymes that metabolize homocysteine (autosomal recessive), vitamin B12 deficiency and/or vitamin B6 deficiency. Hyperhomocysteinemia is considered a risk factor for thrombosis as it alters the function of thrombomodulin, factor VII, and factor V. Excess homocysteine also damage the vasculature leading to decreased endothelial antithrombotic activity. However, this patient has no evidence of anemia due to vitamin B6 or B12 deficiency (fatigue, pallor, tachycardia) or family history of a metabolic disease (enzyme deficiency). Moreover, insensitivity to activated protein C is suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

The prothrombin mutation (G20210A) is the second most common hereditary cause of hypercoagulability. The mutation leads to increased expression of prothrombin. Prothrombin is activated by factor V to form thrombin, which then activates fibrinogen into fibrin to stabilize blood clots. Since laboratory results revealed insensitivity to activated protein C, another choice is more likely to be the cause of this patient's DVT.

G) CORRECT:

Mutation of coagulation factor V (Factor V Leiden) does not allow activated protein C, a potent anticoagulant, to inhibit the coagulation cascade. This causes a procoagulant state by activation of prothrombin into thrombin (i.e., thrombophilia), which has led to this patient's DVT.

See “Pathophysiology of hereditary thrombophilia” table.

H) INCORRECT:

Antithrombin III deficiency accounts for ∼ 0.1% of inherited cases of hypercoagulability and leads to a procoagulable state because of increased levels of thrombin and factor X. Neither of these factors is mentioned in this patient's laboratory studies.

I) INCORRECT:

Protein C along with Protein S are natural anticoagulants in the body. When protein C is activated by thrombin, it complexes with protein S to inhibit factor Va and factor VIIIa. Protein C deficiency is a rare disease with a prevalence of < 1%. Moreover, laboratory results in this patient are not consistent with Protein C deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's history of pulmonary embolism, warfarin use, and clinical features of calf tenderness, swelling, erythema, elevated D-dimer, and noncompressible popliteal vein all indicate deep vein thrombosis. Her lab values point to insensitivity to activated protein C as the underlying cause.

questions.text: An investigator is studying genetic mutations of coagulation factors from patient samples. Genetic sequencing of one patient's coagulation factors shows a DNA point mutation that substitutes guanine for adenine. The corresponding mRNA codon forms a glutamine in place of arginine on position 506 at the polypeptide cleavage site. This patient's disorder is most likely to cause which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Petechiae are seen in association with disorders of the blood vessels or platelet abnormalities. Common conditions in which petechiae can be seen include thrombocytopenic disorders (e.g., ITP), vasculitis, viral hemorrhagic disorders, and vitamin deficiencies (e.g., scurvy). This patient's genetic mutation suggests an underlying thrombophilia disorder and not a bleeding disorder.

B) CORRECT:

Cerebral venous thrombosis is most likely to be associated with this patient's genetic mutation. Factor V Leiden accounts for > 90% of activated protein C (APC) resistance and is caused by a point mutation in the factor V gene that leads to an amino acid substitution that renders factor V resistant to inactivation by APC. Normally, APC inactivates factor V in the clotting cascade and decreases the activation of thrombin. However, in patients with this defect, factor V remains active, activates prothrombin, and increases the risk of thrombotic events. Venous thromboembolism, most commonly DVT or PE, can be seen in patients with factor V Leiden. Cerebral venous thrombosis can also occur, particularly in women that use oral contraceptives.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemarthrosis is seen in association with hemophilia. Hemophilia A and hemophilia B are X-linked recessive disorders of hemostasis. Hemophilia A results from factor VIII deficiency and hemophilia B from factor IX deficiency. Hemophilia can manifest with hemarthrosis and muscular or soft tissue hematomas. Depending on the severity of clotting factor deficiency, bleeding may occur spontaneously or in response to trauma. Repeated hemarthrosis can eventually lead to joint destruction, a serious long-term complication of hemophilia. The patient's genetic mutation described in this vignette suggests an underlying thrombophilia disorder and not a bleeding disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency is more commonly associated with bleeding disorders. The patient's genetic mutation suggests an underlying thrombophilia disorder and not a bleeding disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Ischemic stroke can occur in association with this patient's condition; however, venous thromboembolism (DVT or PE) is more commonly seen. Arterial thrombosis, ischemic strokes, and transient ischemic attacks are more likely in other hypercoagulable conditions such as antiphospholipid syndrome.
questions.hint: This mutation results in resistance to degradation by activated protein C.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents for follow-up one week after being diagnosed with deep-vein thrombosis (DVT) at an urgent-care clinic, where he presented with pain and swelling in his right leg. He has been treated with apixaban since the diagnosis.
The patient reports no recent travel or surgery. Two years ago, he had a similar episode involving the left leg and received anticoagulation for 6 months. He notes that his mother and sister have also had episodes of DVT. He is concerned about a genetic predisposition to venous thrombosis and would like to be tested at this visit.
If a decision is made to initiate testing at this visit, which of the following tests, if any, could provide accurate information?

choices.text: Factor V Leiden and prothrombin gene-mutation testing
No tests can provide accurate information at this time
Protein C activity, protein S activity, antithrombin activity, factor V Leiden mutation, prothrombin gene mutation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A young patient with two unprovoked episodes of venous thromboembolism (VTE) is at above-average risk for an inherited predisposition to thrombophilia, particularly if there is also a family history of VTE. Many such patients are tested for the major inherited disorders that predispose to VTE.

There is no clear consensus on whom to test, because testing often will not change management — particularly for patients in whom indefinite anticoagulation is recommended regardless of the presence or absence of an inherited thrombophilia. Some authorities recommend identification of inherited thrombophilias so that the patient’s asymptomatic relatives can be screened; others, however, argue that the therapeutic implications for asymptomatic relatives who test positive are unclear.

If a decision is made to test, clinicians should consider the timing of the tests carefully, because some of the results may be affected by whether the patient has an acute thrombosis or is taking anticoagulation. For example, testing for protein C, protein S, and antithrombin activity should not be performed early in the course of VTE or during anticoagulation therapy:

• Acute thrombosis can reduce levels of protein C, protein S, and antithrombin activity — and can therefore suggest inherited deficiency when none actually exists.
• Heparin can reduce antithrombin activity.
• Warfarin can reduce protein C and protein S activity.
• Apixaban has been reported to increase the results for antithrombin, protein C, and protein S activity.
• Other direct oral anticoagulants have also been associated with various changes in these measurements.

Genetic testing for factor V Leiden and the prothrombin gene mutation can be ordered at any time, as neither acute thrombosis nor anticoagulant treatment will change the results.

Key learning point: The main tests that can detect a predisposition for venous thromboembolism in a patient with a recent deep-vein thrombosis who is taking anticoagulation are those for factor V Leiden and prothrombin gene mutations.

B) INCORRECT:

A young patient with two unprovoked episodes of venous thromboembolism (VTE) is at above-average risk for an inherited predisposition to thrombophilia, particularly if there is also a family history of VTE. Testing for certain thrombophilias can be ordered at any time, as neither acute thrombosis nor anticoagulant treatment will change the results.

C) INCORRECT:

Testing for protein C, protein S, and antithrombin activity should not be performed early in the course of venous thromboembolism or during anticoagulation therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

While testing for the Factor V Leiden mutation can be performed at any time, it is not the only test that can be accurately conducted in the presence of acute thrombosis or while the patient is on anticoagulation therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

While testing for the prothrombin gene mutation can be performed at any time, it is not the only test that can be accurately conducted in the presence of acute thrombosis or while the patient is on anticoagulation therapy.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man receiving systemic chemotherapy for stage III lung cancer reports a 2-week history of a painful superficial thrombophlebitis and new-onset, acute pain in his right foot.
Physical examination shows a patient in pain. His temperature is 37°C, his respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and his blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg. His right foot is cool to the touch, with skin mottling and an absent dorsalis pedis pulse.
His international normalized ratio is 1.1.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.5
13.5–17.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
3900
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
115,000
150,000–350,000


Partial-thromboplastin time (sec)
28.0
22.1–35.1



Fibrinogen (mg/dL)
110
150–400


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.8–1.3


D-dimer (μg/mL)
2.0
<0.5


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This case does not have the typical features of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, which include fever, central nervous system abnormalities, and renal insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia typically develops in patients with hepatitis C virus or HIV infection and has clinical features such as skin lesions, arthralgia, and weakness.

C) INCORRECT:

Although bacterial endocarditis might be a possibility, infective endocarditis is not usually associated with superficial venous thrombophlebitis.

D) CORRECT:

Superficial venous thrombophlebitis and arterial thromboembolism (from nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis) are essential features of the cancer-associated hypercoagulable state related to chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The process is triggered by tissue factor released from tumor cells. The prothrombin time and partial-thromboplastin time can be normal in chronic DIC. The low level of fibrinogen and high D-dimer level in this patient suggest ongoing clotting and fibrinogen consumption.

Key learning point: The findings of superficial venous thrombophlebitis and arterial thromboembolism in a patient with cancer is most consistent with the diagnosis of cancer-associated hypercoagulable state.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome can involve both venous and arterial thrombosis; however, the presence of lung cancer makes chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation from a cancer-associated hypercoagulable state much more likely.

questions.text:
A young man, 19 years of age, reports several months of dyspnea on exertion. He has occasional palpitations and dizziness with activity, as well as intermittent episodes of diffuse abdominal pain. He reports no chest pain, lower-extremity edema, and orthopnea. He has a history of portal-vein thrombosis, for which he received rivaroxaban for 6 months. He currently takes no medications.
Physical examination reveals regular tachycardia with a heart rate of 104 beats per minute, mild scleral icterus, no murmurs or gallops, clear lungs, no abdominal tenderness, no lower-extremity edema, and a normal skin assessment.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
3000
4500–11,000


Neutrophils (%)
40
40–70


Neutrophil count (per mm3)
1200
1900–7600



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10
13.5–17.5


Hematocrit (%)
30
41–53


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
99
80–100



Platelet count (per mm3)
90,000
150,000–350,000


Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
6.0
0.5–2.5



Haptoglobin (mg/dL)
<8
16–199


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.8–1.3


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
2.5
0.3–1.0


Direct bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.3
0.1–0.3



Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
472
100–190


Prothrombin time, partial-thromboplastin time, and D-dimer are within normal limits. A peripheral-blood smear reveals normal platelets, some macrocytic red cells, and polychromasia. Urinalysis shows 2 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and no leukocytes. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is unlikely, given the lack of schistocytes on peripheral-blood smear.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is unlikely, given the lack of spherocytes on peripheral-blood smear and the negative direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test.

C) INCORRECT:

Disseminated intravascular coagulation is unlikely, given the normal coagulation studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Although abdominal pain occurs with some forms of porphyria, the rest of the patient’s presentation is not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia, a history of portal-vein thrombosis, and pancytopenia together suggest a diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

PNH is a rare, acquired bone-marrow disorder caused by mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan anchor gene, leading to the partial absence or complete absence of glycosylphosphatidylinositol-linked proteins (e.g., CD55 and CD59) on blood cells. PNH cells are susceptible to complement-mediated lysis that occurs in the intravascular space and causes hemoglobinuria/hemosiderinuria and episodes of dark urine.

Thrombosis, the most common cause of death in patients with PNH, may occur in unusual sites. Some patients with PNH experience bone-marrow failure resulting in pancytopenia. PNH is associated with increased risk for myelodysplastic syndrome, aplastic anemia, and leukemia.

First-line therapy for hemolytic PNH is eculizumab, a monoclonal antibody against the complement protein C5.

Key learning point: The triad of the most prominent clinical features of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and pancytopenia.

His father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 30 years. Physical examination shows a tender and mildly swollen left lower leg; dorsiflexion of the left foot causes severe pain in the calf. Despite receiving a therapeutic dose of heparin, this patient's partial thromboplastin time (PTT) increases minimally and remains within normal limits, suggesting a defect in the protein targeted by heparin.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pain and swelling of her left leg over the past 24 hours. The pain is worse while walking and improves when resting. Seven months ago, she was diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism and was started on warfarin. Anticoagulant therapy was discontinued 1 month ago. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. On physical examination, the left calf is diffusely erythematous, swollen, and tender. Dorsal flexion of the left foot elicits pain. On duplex ultrasonography, the left popliteal vein is not compressible. Laboratory studies show an elevated serum concentration of D-dimer and insensitivity to activated protein C. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antithrombin III deficiency accounts for ∼ 0.1% of inherited cases of hypercoagulability and leads to a procoagulable state because of increased levels of thrombin and factor X. Neither of these factors is mentioned in this patient's laboratory studies.

B) INCORRECT:

Protein S along with protein C are natural anticoagulants in the body. When protein C is activated by thrombin, it combines with protein S to inhibit factor Va and factor VIIIa. Deficiency of protein S can therefore lead to hypercoagulability. However, protein S deficiency has a prevalence of < 1% in the general population, which makes another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is caused by acquired antibodies directed against phospholipids bound to plasma proteins such as lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, and anti-β2-glycoprotein I. This interaction leads to the aggregation of clotting factors, resulting in thrombus formation. Although this patient has a family history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and presents with hypercoagulability, her lack of other typical manifestations of SLE (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity, arthritis) makes this diagnosis less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Mutation of coagulation factor V (Factor V Leiden) does not allow activated protein C, a potent anticoagulant, to inhibit the coagulation cascade, leading to a procoagulant state by activation of prothrombin into thrombin (i.e., thrombophilia). Consider a hereditary thrombophilia in a young, otherwise healthy patient with venous thromboembolism with no obvious risk factors. Factor V Leiden is the most common inherited thrombophilia.

See table “Pathophysiology of hereditary thrombophilia.”
Image Description:

Clotting homeostasis is maintained through a balance of procoagulation (purple) and anticoagulation (gray) processes. The procoagulation pathway ultimately results in the enzymatic conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin, which is an integral part of blood clot formation. The procoagulation pathway is physiologically inhibited through two distinct anticoagulation pathways, using either antithrombin III or the APC complex.

Antithrombin III inactivates factors IX, X, and thrombin. This process is accelerated in the presence of heparin. Additionally, antithrombin III indirectly increases the activation of plasmin through the action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), resulting in the degradation of both fibrinogen and fibrin.

The APC complex pathway involves the activity of thrombomodulin, a membrane protein expressed on endothelial cells that activates protein C. Activated protein C then binds to protein S to form the APC complex, which inactivates procoagulation factors V and VIII. The procoagulation factor thrombin can also activate protein C, which results in a negative feedback loop on the procoagulation pathway.

E) INCORRECT:

Protein C along with protein S are natural anticoagulants in the body. When protein C is activated by thrombin, it complexes with protein S to inhibit factor Va and factor VIIIa. Protein C deficiency is a rare disease with a prevalence of < 1%. Moreover, laboratory results in this patient are not consistent with protein C deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's history of pulmonary embolism, warfarin use, and clinical features of calf tenderness, swelling, erythema, elevated D-dimer, and noncompressible popliteal vein indicate a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. Her laboratory studies implicate insensitivity to activated protein C as the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 0, aborta 3, comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent abortions. Each pregnancy resulted in spontaneous abortion in the second trimester. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. The patient has a history of chronic migraines, Raynaud phenomenon, and occasional joint pain. She appears tired. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a purple, reticular rash on both calves. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia can lead to cryoglobulinemic vasculitis, which can manifest with arthralgia, palpable purpura, and Raynaud syndrome. In over 90% of cases, it is associated with hepatitis C. This patient does not show any symptoms of hepatitis C (e.g., malaise, nausea, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice). In addition, neither cryoglobulinemic vasculitis nor hepatitis C causes recurrent abortions.

B) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count can help evaluate for disorders that are associated with recurrent abortions, including thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. This patient, however, does not present with symptoms of TTP (e.g., fever, neurologic signs, signs of low platelet count, hemolytic anemia) or take heparin.

C) INCORRECT:

The major clinical manifestation of factor V Leiden is venous thromboembolism, although heterozygote patients are often asymptomatic. Though women with factor V Leiden may have a higher risk for recurrent loss of pregnancy. This condition is not associated with Raynaud syndrome, arthralgia, or livedo reticularis.

D) CORRECT:

In antiphospholipid syndrome (APLS), antibodies are directed against phospholipids, including cardiolipin, which is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane. Anticardiolipin antibodies are associated with several diseases, including SLE and APLS. As this patient most likely has SLE (joint pain, Raynaud syndrome, livedo reticularis) and has had three consecutive abortions, APLS should be suspected. The diagnosis is confirmed by testing for antiphospholipid antibodies (e.g., anticardiolipin antibodies, anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies, lupus anticoagulant). Systemic anticoagulation (e.g., LMWH) is the cornerstone of APS treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

A peripheral blood smear to identify sickle cells is a preliminary test to diagnose sickle cell disease (SCD). This condition is associated with obstetric complications including preeclampsia, vaso-occlusive episodes, and anemia, and can uncommonly cause recurrent abortions. However, SCD is not associated with Raynaud syndrome, arthralgia, or livedo reticularis.
questions.hint: The patient's joint pain, Raynaud phenomenon, and livedo reticularis are suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). One comorbid condition of SLE causes thrombosis and recurrent abortions.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman presents with a 4-week history of a purple, reticular rash on her lower extremities and several hemorrhagic necrotic blisters. She reports a history of three spontaneous abortions, including one in the second trimester. A photograph of her medial left knee is shown. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8000/mm3



Platelet count
200,000/mm3



Serum



Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.1 mg/dL


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
28 mm/hr


C-reactive protein
9 mg/L


Her baseline serum creatinine concentration was 1.0 mg/dL three months ago. A skin biopsy of the blisters shows nonvasculitic small-vessel vasculopathy with microthrombi. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Factor V Leiden is a hereditary thrombophilia that raises the risk of thrombotic events by increasing prothrombin activation. Although this hypercoagulable state can contribute to recurrent pregnancy loss by promoting abnormal blood clot formation, it typically causes venous thromboses (e.g., DVT, cerebral vein thrombosis) rather than arterial or microvascular thrombi.

B) INCORRECT:

Essential thrombocythemia increases the risk of recurrent pregnancy loss and thromboembolic events due to the uncontrolled proliferation of platelets. However, this patient has a normal platelet count and does not have other features of essential thrombocythemia, such as vasomotor symptoms, acute gouty arthritis, or petechial bleeding.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation and history of multiple spontaneous abortions are consistent with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). This syndrome is diagnosed in patients with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss and/or an arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis who test positive for at least one of the following on two occasions 12 weeks apart: anti-beta2-glycoprotein antibodies, high-titer anticardiolipin antibodies, or lupus anticoagulants. An ulcerating skin rash without palpable nodules or papules suggests an occlusive vasculopathy, for which a skin biopsy should be considered. This patient's rising serum creatinine level could be caused by APS-related thrombotic vasculopathy in the kidneys. Systemic anticoagulation is the cornerstone of treatment for thrombotic APS.

Key learning point: The combination of a vasculopathic skin rash with microthrombi, acute kidney injury, and a history of multiple miscarriages is consistent with a diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Calciphylaxis is a severe cutaneous vasculopathy that is usually associated with chronic renal insufficiency and often manifests with livedo reticularis and necrotic skin ulcerations. However, this condition is most commonly seen in patients with end-stage renal disease and is not associated with recurrent pregnancy loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis of small to medium-sized arteries that can cause cutaneous ulcers and renal insufficiency. This condition is not associated with a history of multiple spontaneous abortions, and an ulcerating skin rash more likely suggests vasculopathy than vasculitis. Furthermore, biopsy findings in polyarteritis nodosa show transmural inflammation of the arterial wall rather than small-vessel vasculopathy with microthrombi.
questions.hint: A purple reticular rash with necrotic blisters indicates livedo reticularis with ulcerations.

questions.text: You are seeing a 24-year-old woman who presents with a 24-hour history of pain and swelling in her left leg. The pain worsens with walking and improves with rest. She was diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism 7 months ago and started on warfarin, which was discontinued 1 month ago. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. On examination, her left calf is diffusely erythematous, swollen, and tender. Dorsiflexion of the left foot elicits pain. Duplex ultrasonography shows that the left popliteal vein is not compressible. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated serum D-dimer (> 600 μg/L) and insensitivity to activated protein C. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antithrombin III deficiency accounts for ∼ 0.1% of inherited cases of hypercoagulability and leads to a procoagulable state because of increased levels of thrombin and factor X. Neither of these factors is mentioned in this patient's laboratory studies.

B) CORRECT:

Mutation of coagulation factor V (Factor V Leiden) does not allow activated protein C, a potent anticoagulant, to inhibit the coagulation cascade, leading to a procoagulant state by activation of prothrombin into thrombin (i.e., thrombophilia). Consider a hereditary thrombophilia in a young, otherwise healthy patient with venous thromboembolism with no obvious risk factors. Factor V Leiden is the most common inherited thrombophilia.

See table “Pathophysiology of hereditary thrombophilia.”

Key learning point: Activated protein C resistance, the most common inherited thrombophilia, is caused by the factor V Leiden mutation, which increases the risk of venous thromboembolism.
Image Description:

Clotting homeostasis is maintained through a balance of procoagulation (purple) and anticoagulation (gray) processes. The procoagulation pathway ultimately results in the enzymatic conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin, which is an integral part of blood clot formation. The procoagulation pathway is physiologically inhibited through two distinct anticoagulation pathways, using either antithrombin III or the APC complex.

Antithrombin III inactivates factors IX, X, and thrombin. This process is accelerated in the presence of heparin. Additionally, antithrombin III indirectly increases the activation of plasmin through the action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), resulting in the degradation of both fibrinogen and fibrin.

The APC complex pathway involves the activity of thrombomodulin, a membrane protein expressed on endothelial cells that activates protein C. Activated protein C then binds to protein S to form the APC complex, which inactivates procoagulation factors V and VIII. The procoagulation factor thrombin can also activate protein C, which results in a negative feedback loop on the procoagulation pathway.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is caused by acquired antibodies directed against phospholipids bound to plasma proteins such as lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, and anti-β2-glycoprotein I. This interaction leads to the aggregation of clotting factors, resulting in thrombus formation. Although this patient has a family history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and presents with hypercoagulability, her lack of other typical manifestations of SLE (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity, arthritis) makes this diagnosis less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Protein C along with protein S are natural anticoagulants in the body. When protein C is activated by thrombin, it complexes with protein S to inhibit factor Va and factor VIIIa. Protein C deficiency is a rare disease with a prevalence of < 1%. Moreover, laboratory results in this patient are not consistent with protein C deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Protein S along with protein C are natural anticoagulants in the body. When protein C is activated by thrombin, it combines with protein S to inhibit factor Va and factor VIIIa. Deficiency of protein S can therefore lead to hypercoagulability. However, protein S deficiency has a prevalence of < 1% in the general population, which makes another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This patient's history of pulmonary embolism, warfarin use, and clinical features of calf tenderness, swelling, erythema, elevated D-dimer, and noncompressible popliteal vein indicate a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. Her laboratory studies implicate insensitivity to activated protein C as the underlying cause.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-week history of a purple, reticular rash on her lower extremities and several hemorrhagic necrotic blisters. She has a history of three spontaneous abortions, including one in the second trimester. A photograph of her medial left knee is provided. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
125 g/L (115–155)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
8.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
200 × 109/L (130–380)


Urea, blood
5.7 mmol/L (2.1–8.0)


Creatinine, blood

186 μmol/L (22–75)


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), blood
28 mm/h (0–20)


C-reactive protein, blood
9 mg/L (≤ 10)


Her baseline serum creatinine was 88 μmol/L (22–75) three months ago. A skin biopsy of the blisters shows nonvasculitic small-vessel vasculopathy with microthrombi. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation and history of multiple spontaneous abortions are consistent with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). This syndrome is diagnosed in patients with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss and/or an arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis who test positive for at least one of the following on two occasions 12 weeks apart: anti-beta2-glycoprotein antibodies, high-titer anticardiolipin antibodies, or lupus anticoagulants. An ulcerating skin rash without palpable nodules or papules suggests an occlusive vasculopathy, for which a skin biopsy should be considered. This patient's rising serum creatinine level could be caused by APS-related thrombotic vasculopathy in the kidneys. Systemic anticoagulation is the cornerstone of treatment for thrombotic APS.

Key learning point: The combination of a vasculopathic skin rash with microthrombi, acute kidney injury, and a history of multiple miscarriages is consistent with a diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis of small to medium-sized arteries that can cause cutaneous ulcers and renal insufficiency. This condition is not associated with a history of multiple spontaneous abortions, and an ulcerating skin rash more likely suggests vasculopathy than vasculitis. Furthermore, biopsy findings in polyarteritis nodosa show transmural inflammation of the arterial wall rather than small-vessel vasculopathy with microthrombi.

C) INCORRECT:

Essential thrombocythemia increases the risk of recurrent pregnancy loss and thromboembolic events due to the uncontrolled proliferation of platelets. However, this patient has a normal platelet count and does not have other features of essential thrombocythemia, such as vasomotor symptoms, acute gouty arthritis, or petechial bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Calciphylaxis is a severe cutaneous vasculopathy that is usually associated with chronic renal insufficiency and often manifests with livedo reticularis and necrotic skin ulcerations. However, this condition is most commonly seen in patients with end-stage renal disease and is not associated with recurrent pregnancy loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Factor V Leiden is a hereditary thrombophilia that raises the risk of thrombotic events by increasing prothrombin activation. Although this hypercoagulable state can contribute to recurrent pregnancy loss by promoting abnormal blood clot formation, it typically causes venous thromboses (e.g., DVT, cerebral vein thrombosis) rather than arterial or microvascular thrombi.
questions.hint: A purple reticular rash with necrotic blisters indicates livedo reticularis with ulcerations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with acute onset left leg pain and swelling that developed over 2 days. She has no recent travel, surgery, or immobilization. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive pill started 3 months ago. Doppler ultrasound confirms proximal deep venous thrombosis of the left femoral vein. Anticoagulation is initiated. Her 34-year-old sister had pulmonary embolism at age 30, and her maternal aunt died of stroke at age 45. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Obtain CT angiogram of the chest
Refer to hematology for thrombophilia evaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no clinical indication for pulmonary embolism evaluation in this patient who presents with isolated lower extremity symptoms and has confirmed DVT without respiratory symptoms or signs of hemodynamic compromise. 

B) INCORRECT:

Inpatient admission is not indicated for uncomplicated proximal DVT in a hemodynamically stable patient without contraindications to outpatient anticoagulation. The patient can be safely managed as an outpatient with appropriate follow-up.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignancy screening with CT abdomen and pelvis is generally indicated for unprovoked VTE in patients over age 50 years; this would not be the most appropriate step in this young patient with clear thrombophilia risk factors and family history.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient demonstrates clinical features suggestive of underlying thrombophilia: VTE at age less than 50 years associated with only weak risk factors, and strong family history of thromboembolism at young ages. Patients with these characteristics should be considered for referral to a specialist for thrombophilia evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

While routine follow-up is appropriate, this patient's clinical features suggestive of underlying thrombophilia warrant specialist evaluation rather than routine care alone.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with right calf pain and swelling for 2 days. She denies travel, trauma, estrogen use, or recent surgery. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 96; R, 18; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F). Duplex ultrasonography confirms an occlusive thrombus in the anterior tibial vein. Laboratory studies show platelets 260 ×10³/mm³, PT 12 seconds, INR 1.0, and PTT 31 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate management approach?

choices.text: Begin low–molecular-weight heparin followed by dabigatran and arrange primary care follow-up
Begin low–molecular-weight heparin and arrange repeat ultrasound in one week
Begin apixaban and arrange hematology follow-up
Admit for intravenous heparin therapy and diagnostic testing
Begin warfarin and arrange primary care follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although anticoagulation is appropriate, an additional step is required in this patient with unprovoked DVT.

B) INCORRECT:

Routine follow-up imaging to document resolution is unnecessary. Also, an additional step is required in this patient with unprovoked DVT.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Deep vein thrombosis in a young patient without transient risk factors constitutes unprovoked thrombosis. Management in the emergency department involves initiating anticoagulation and ensuring outpatient hematology follow-up for evaluation of possible inherited or acquired hypercoagulability.

D) INCORRECT:

Hospitalization is not required for a hemodynamically stable patient with isolated lower-extremity DVT.

E) INCORRECT:

When warfarin is used for anticoagulation, bridging therapy is required until INR becomes therapeutic, making warfarin monotherapy inappropriate. Also, an additional step is required in this patient with unprovoked DVT.
